aslsd.models

Submodules

aslsd.models.mhp

class aslsd.models.mhp.MHP(_kernel_matrix, d=None, matrix_n_param=None, n_ker_param=None, ix_map=None, interval_map=None, mu_names=None, ker_param_names=None, param_bounds=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, is_fitted=False, fitted_mu=None, fitted_ker_param=None, fit_residuals=None, fitted_adjacency=None, fit_log=None)

Bases: object

Class for multivariate Hawkes processes (MHP) models.

Let \(\mathbf{N}\) be a d-dimensional counting process with conditional intensity \(\boldsymbol{\lambda}\). We say that \(\mathbf{N}\) is a (linear) MHP if, for all \(i \in[d]\) and for all \(t \geq 0\), we have

\[\lambda_{i}(t):=\mu_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \sum_{\left\{m: t_{m}^{j}<t\right\}} \phi_{ij}\left(t-t_{m}^{j}\right),\]

where

  • \(\forall i,j \in [d], \phi_{ij}:[0,+\infty) \to [0,+\infty)\) is in \(L_{1}\). We write \(\boldsymbol{\phi}=(\phi_{ij})_{i,j\in [d]}\). The functions \(\phi_{i j}\) are called the kernels of the MHP;

  • \(\forall i \in[d], \mu_{i}>0\). The floats \(\mu_{i}\) are called baseline intensities.

For all \(i,j \in [d]\), and for all \(t \geq 0\), define

\[\psi_{ij}(t):=\int_0^t \phi_{ij}(u)\mathrm{d}u.\]

We write \(\boldsymbol{\psi}=(\psi_{ij})_{ij\in [d]}\).

For all \(i,j,k \in [d]\), and for all \(t,s \geq 0\), define

\[\Upsilon_{ijk}(t,s):=\int_0^t \phi_{ki}(u)\phi_{kj}(u+s)\mathrm{d}u.\]

We write \(\boldsymbol{\Upsilon}=(\Upsilon_{ijk})_{ijk\in [d]}\).

In our implementation, the class attribute

  • phi denotes the matrix of kernel functions \(\boldsymbol{\phi}\), such that phi[i][j] is the kernel function \(\phi_{ij}\);

  • psi denotes the matrix of primitive functions \(\boldsymbol{\psi}\), such that psi[i][j] is the primitive function \(\psi_{ij}\);

  • upsilon denotes the tensor of correlation functions \(\boldsymbol{\Upsilon}\), such that upsilon[i][j][k] is the correlation function \(\Upsilon_{ijk}\).

clear_fit()

Delete all previously saved results and logs from the corresponding attributes of the MHP object.

fit(list_times, T_f, kappa=None, varpi=None, x_0=None, n_iter=1000, solvers=None, estimators=None, logger=None, seed=1234, verbose=False, clear=True, write=True, **kwargs)

Fit the MHP model to some observations.

We suppose that we observe a path of a d-dimensional counting process \(\mathbf{N}\) started at time \(0\) up to some terminal time \(T\).

The least squares error (LSE) of this model for these observations is defined as

\[\mathcal{R}_{T}(\boldsymbol{\mu}):=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{k=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{T} \lambda_{k}(t)^{2} \mathrm{~d} t-\frac{2}{T} \sum_{k=1}^{d} \sum_{m=1}^{N_{T}^{k}} \lambda_{k}\left(t_{m}^{k}\right).\]

For a homogeneous Poisson model, this simplifies to

\[\mathcal{R}_{T}(\boldsymbol{\mu}):=\sum_{k=1}^{d} \bigg( \mu_{k}^{2} -2 \frac{N_{T}^{k}}{T} \bigg).\]
Parameters

  • list_times (list of numpy.ndarray) – List of jump times for each dimension.

  • T_f (float) – Terminal time.

  • kappa (TYPE, optional) – DESCRIPTION. The default is None.

  • varpi (TYPE, optional) – DESCRIPTION. The default is None.

  • x_0 (list of numpy.ndarray, optional) – x_0[k] is the initial guess for parameters of problem k. The default is None.

  • n_iter (list or int, optional) – n_iter[k] is the number of iterations of the the optimisation algorithm for problem k. If n_iter is of type int, it will be converted to a d-dimensional array where each entry is equal to that integer. The default is 1000.

  • solvers (list of aslsd.Solver, optional) – solvers[k] is the optimization solver for problem k. The default is None.

  • estimators (list of aslsd.Esimtator, optional) – estimators[k] is the gradient estimator for problem k. The default is None.

  • logger (aslsd.OptimLogger, optional) – DESCRIPTION. The default is None.

  • seed (int, optional) – Seed for the random number generator. The default is 1234.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, print progression information. The default is False.

  • clear (bool, optional) – If true, delete all previously saved results and logs from the corresponding attributes of the MHP object. The default is True.

  • write (bool, optional) – If true, save the estimation results and logs in the corresponding attributes of the MHP object. The default is True.

  • **kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments.

Returns

  • fitted_mu (numpy.ndarray) – Fitted baselines.

  • fitted_ker_param (numpy.ndarray) – Fitted kernel parameters.

get_branching_ratio(adjacency=None, kernel_param=None)

Compute the branching ratio of the MHP.

The branching ratio of an MHP is equal to the spectral radius of its adjacency matrix; that is, the maximum of the absolute values of the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix.

Parameters

  • adjacency (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Adjacency matrix of the MHP. The default is None, in that case it will be computed.

  • kernel_param (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Matrix of kernel parameters at which to evaluate the adjacency matrix. The default is None, in that case fitted kernel parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the adjacency matrix is not specified, the kernel parameters not specified and there are no kernel parameters saved as an atrribute.

Returns

adjacency – Branching ratio of the MHP.

Return type

float

get_l2_projection(mhp_2, param_2, n_iter=1000, solver=None, log_error=False, rng=None, seed=1234, verbose=False, **kwargs)
get_n_param()

Get the matrix of number of parameters per kernel model.

If we denote by \(M\) this matrix and by \(d\) the dimensionality of the MHP model, then \(M\) is a \(d\times d\) matrix which entry \(M_{ij}\) is the number of parameters of kernel \(\phi_{ij}\).

Returns

mat_n_param – Matrix of number of parameters per kernel model.

Return type

list of list of int

Returns

mat_n_param – Matrix of number of parameters per kernel model.

get_random_param(ref_mu=None, ref_ker_param=None, range_ref=0.1, target_bratio=0.6, max_omega=1.0, true_omega=None, max_param=5.0, min_mu=0.0, max_mu=None, flatten=False, seed=1234, rng=None)
get_residuals(process_path, mu=None, kernel_param=None, sampling=False, sample_size=1000, seed=1234, write=True, verbose=False)

Compute the residuals of the model.

We suppose that we observe a path of a d-dimensional counting process \(\mathbf{N}\) started at time \(0\) up to some terminal time \(T\).

Let \(k \in [d]\), define the compensator of \(N^k\) for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[\Lambda_{k}(t):=\int_{[0,t]}\lambda_k(t)\mathrm{~d} t.\]

For all \(m \in \mathbb{N}^{*}, k \in [d]\), let

\[s_{m}^{k}=\Lambda_{k}\left(t_{m}^{k}\right).\]

For each \(k \in[d]\), define the point process

\[\mathcal{S}^{k}:=\left\{s_{m}^{k}: m \in \mathbb{N}^{*}\right\};\]

then \(\left(\mathcal{S}^{k}\right)_{k \in[d]}\) are independent standard Poisson processes. The inter-arrival times of \(\mathcal{S}^{k}\) (‘residuals’), for a model that fits the data well must therefore be close to a standard exponential distribution.

Parameters

  • process_path (aslsd.ProcessPath) – DESCRIPTION.

  • mu (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Vector of baseline parameters. The default is None, in that case fitted baseline parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

  • kernel_param (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Matrix of kernel parameters. The default is None, in that case fitted kernel parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

  • sampling (bool, optional) – If True, subsample the residuals. The default is False.

  • sample_size (int, optional) – Size of the subsample of residuals. The default is 10**3. Only used if sampling is True.

  • seed (int, optional) – Seed of the random number generator. The default is 1234. Only used if sampling is true.

  • write (bool, optional) – If true, save computed residuals in the corresponding attributes of the MHP object. The default is True.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, print progress bar. The default is False.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the baseline is not specified and there is no fitted baseline saved as an atrribute.

Returns

residuals – Residuals of the fitted model.

Return type

list of numpy.ndarray

property kernel_matrix

Kernel matrix of the MHP. Setting the kernel matrix to a new value will automatically modify the values of the other attributes that depend on it.

ks_test_residuals(residuals=None)

make_adjacency_matrix(kernel_param=None)

Compute the adjacency matrix of the MHP.

The adjacency matrix \(A\) of an MHP is the \(d\times d\) matrix of \(L_{1}\) norms of kernels; that is, for all \(i,j \in [d]\) the corresponding entry of this matrix is given by

\[A_{ij} := \int_{[0,+\infty]} |\phi_{ij}(u)|du..\]
Parameters

kernel_param (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Matrix of kernel parameters at which to evaluate the adjacency matrix. The default is None, in that case fitted kernel parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the kernel parameters not specified and there are no kernel parameters saved as an atrribute.

Returns

adjacency – Adjacency matrix of the MHP.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

make_kernel_functionals()
make_maps()

Compute the mapping between the MHP parameter indices and the flattened vectors of parameters.

Denote by \(d\) the dimensionality of the MHP model. For all \(i, j \in [d]\), denote the vector of parameters of the kernel \(\phi_{i j}\) by \(\vartheta_{i j}\), the dimension of \(\vartheta_{i j}\) by \(\rho_{i j}\), and the total number of event type \(k\) parameters of the model by

\[n^{(k)}_{\text {param }}:=1+\sum_{i=1}^{d} \rho_{k i},\]

where the additive term \(1\) in the right hand side correspond to the baseline parameter.

For all \(k \in[d]\), concatenate the vectors of event type \(k\) kernel parameters as

\[\vartheta_{k}^{\top}=\left(\vartheta_{k 1}^{\top}, \ldots, \vartheta_{k d}^{\top}\right),\]

and define the vectors of event type \(k\) MHP parameters \(\theta_{k}^{\top}=\left(\mu_{k}, \vartheta_{k}^{\top}\right)\). Finally, define the vector of parameters \(\theta\) of the MHP by

\[\theta^{\top}=\left(\theta_{1}^{\top}, \ldots, \theta_{d}^{\top}\right) .\]

The vector of event type \(k\) MHP parameters, \(\theta_{k}\), is the vector of dimension \(n^{(k)}_{\text {param }}\) containing the baseline parameter \(\mu_{k}\) and the parameters of all kernels \((\phi_{kj})_{j \in [d]}\).

The list ix_map is such that for all \(k \in [d]\), and for all \(i \in n_k\), ix_map[k][i] is a dictionary with keys ker and par. The value ix_map[k][i][‘ker’] is an integer representing the index j such that the i-th parameter of the flat vector of parameters is a parameter of the kernel \(\phi_{kj}\). By default, since the 0-th parameter of the flat vector corresponds to the background rate \(\mu_k\), we set ix_map[k][0][‘ker’] to -1. Now let j=ix_map[k][i][‘ker’]. The value ix_map[k][i][‘par’] is an integer representing the index p such that the i-th parameter of the flat vector of parameters is the p-th parameter of the kernel \(\phi_{kj}\). The list interval_map is such that for all \(k \in [d]\), and for all \(j \in [d]\), interval_map[k][j] is a list of two integers [p,q] such that p (resp. q-1) is the index of the first (resp. last) parameter of kernel \(\phi_{kj}\) in the flat vector of parameters.

Returns

  • ix_map (list of list of dict) – DESCRIPTION.

  • interval_map (list of list of int) – Matrix of indices of first and last parameters of kernels in the flat vector of parameters.

Parameters

  • kernel_param (TYPE) – Matrix of kernel parameters.

simulate(T_f, mu=None, kernel_param=None, seed=1234, verbose=False)

Simulate a path of the MHP.

Parameters

  • T_f (float) – Terminal time.

  • mu (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Vector of baseline parameters. The default is None, in that case fitted baseline parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

  • kernel_param (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Matrix of kernel parameters. The default is None, in that case fitted kernel parameters will be used if they are stored in the corresponding attribute of the MHP object.

  • seed (int, optional) – Seed for the random number generator. The default is 1234.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, print progression information. The default is False.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the baseline or the kernel parameters are not specified and there is no fitted baseline or kernel parameters saved as an atrribute.

Returns

list_times – List of simulated jump times for each dimension.

Return type

list of numpy.ndarray
